Description: Huge wine with sweetness and smooth qualities from head to toe. Aromas of mint leaf, pastry and sweet black fruits are magnetic, while the lush, layered palate is complete and packed with berry fruit, toast, fudge and tobacco flavors. Layered and deep on the finish, with cola, herbs and licorice notes. Beautiful wine. Drinkable now and good through 2013.
Name: Benjamin Romeo 2006 La Viña de Andres Romeo  (Rioja)

Description: Starts with the scent of beef on the grill, and then folds in black fruit and fine aged cheese. The palate is as rich and smooth as a silk throw, while flavors of berry, cassis, herbs and coffee cover the bases. Mildly balsamic on the finish, yet not complicated, demanding or overly complex. Drink now through 2012.
Name: Benjamin Romeo 2006 La Cueva del Contador  (Rioja)

Description: Another stellar El Puntido, this time with excellent concentration and full-load aromas of black fruit, leather, fine dried cheese and cola. The palate is tight, properly stretched and racy, with bursting black raspberry and cassis flavors. Coconut and resin on the finish is the first and only glaring announcement of oak. Drink now through 2014.
Name: Viñedos de Paganos 2006 El Puntido  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Protos is a flagship Ribera del Duero property and its wines have been on the rise lately. This is ripe and spicy, with black fruit and then a twitch of prune and moss on the nose. It's racy, pure, forward and stout, with a mix of red and black fruit flavors. Warm and integrated on the finish. Drink now through 2013.
Name: Protos 2004 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: A really nice, dark, modern style of Rioja from a good vintage. The nose is mildly foresty early on and robustly fruity, with stand-out black cherry and blackberry aromas. The palate is full, clean and balanced, with alert flavors of berry, spice, citrus peel and chocolate. Smooth as a glass table on the finish. Drink now through 2014.
Name: Luis Cañas 2004 Amaren  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Just right on the nose, with a smoky, attractive set of deep berry aromas. The palate is pure and composed, with a pure, tasty mix of berry fruit, cocoa and mild oak. Smooth, long and creamy on the finish, and delicious overall. Best wine to date from Emina. Drink now into 2012.
Name: Emina 2006 Prestigio  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Warm, earthy aromas of molasses, moss and baked fruit scream rich and big, and the palate matches that early announcement with cola, baked blackberry, coffee and syrupy flavors. Weighty and forceful, but not without style and a flash of elegance. Pure Toro; drink now through 2012.
Name: Cyan 2003 Prestigio  (Toro)

Description: Jammy and sweet smelling, with intensity and a lot of ripeness. Throughout it teeters on the precipice of being overripe, but amid the chunky darkness and sweetness there's tasty berry, chocolate and spice. Finishes a bit pruney and raisiny, so get at it as soon as you can.
Name: Marqués de Cáceres 2004 Gaudium  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Full, earthy and ripe, but also delivering alot of clean fruit, size and balance. The palate has moderate to full tannic grip, which props up berry, vanilla, wood and mild herbal flavors. Long, solid and a little oaky late, with proper purity and a commitment to the near future. Drink now through 2011.
Name: Val Sotillo 2005 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: An attractive, ripe wine that pushes up against raisiny but then draws back to focus on blackberry, licorice and other dark aromas and flavors. Very good weight and mouthfeel, with nice balance supporting ripe berry, cola and mild chocolate flavors. Finishes lush and warm. Drink now through 2011.
Name: Finca Torremilanos 2005 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Pine needle, cedar plank and forest floor define the mature nose, while the full, grabby, tannic palate is loaded with likable cola, black fruit and chocolate flavors. Ripe, pure, rich and tannic, with some bite, burn and ruggedness. Drinkable now but needs food to cut the tannins.
Name: Val de Los Frailes 2003 Prestigio Tempranillo (Cigales)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A round, chewy wine with a nice mix of black fruit, vanilla, aged cheese and light balsam wood on the nose. The palate is big but doesn't bite back, and the flavors of creamy berry are broad and nice. A very solid wine with weight and heat; drink now through 2011.
Name: Bodegas Imperiales 2004 Abadia de San Quirce Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This wine gets it right. The color is dark and opaque, while the nose offers perfume, Middle Eastern spice, fruitcake and solid black fruit. Enticing in the mouth, where full black fruit flavors are pumped up by fine herb and spice notes. And then coffee and chocolate fill the finish. Drink now through 2010.
Name: Finca El Quiñón 2006 Jaros  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: A solid, serious Rioja reserva with licorice, leather, char and good berry aromas. The palate is juicy, pure and tastes of clean black cherry and cola flavors. Picks up steam as it opens up, and then finishes with a light butter streak and proper weight. No complaints; almost makes the upper echelon. Drink now through 2012.
Name: Bodegas Palacio 2004 Cosme Palacio y Hermanos Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Opens with floral, blueberry aromas, mineral notes and a spot of jammy candy. The palate is alert and well balanced, with grab and juicy flavors of raspberry and plum offset by a wave of buttery oak. Textured, full and satisfying on the finish. Very nice wine.
Name: Legaris 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Ripe, stout and concentrated on the bouquet, with cassis and lightly roasted berry aromas. Solid and tannic in the mouth, with full plum and cherry flavors. Finishes big and friendly, with a very mild herbal undertone and a slight dose of sauciness. Very nice RDD.
Name: Matarromera 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Bold and chunky Ribera wine with black fruit aromas that don't tread lightly. The palate is lush and features a nice overall feel, while the flavors of berry fruit and chocolate hint at raisin but don't fully cross the threshhold. Heavier and darker than prior years. Drink now.
Name: Comenge 2006  Ribera del Duero

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Incognito deftly describes the unusual beet and blueberry aromas on this wine, which is a bit narrow and scracthy. On the plus side, it's concentrated and powerful, with bold berry flavors, tannic grip and herbal influences. Chunky on the finish but lacks the precision and identifiable Ribera del Duero character that a $75 wine should have.
Name: Terra Incognita 2004  Ribera del Duero

Description: Coconut and vanilla aromas are squarely in the lead, but the nose's berry base is more than solid. Plump, round and showing good overall balance, with flavors of cola, dark fruit and coconut. A ripe, bulky crianza with plenty of leftover oak on the finish.
Name: Ramirez de la Piscina 2006 Selección Crianza  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: There's an exotic twist to the nose, which rests on black cherry, plum and a splash of black coffee. The palate is sound and structured, with dark fruit flavors accented by spice and tea notes. Comfortable on the finish, with good tannins and acids holding it all together. Drink now.
Name: Bodegas Qumrán 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A blend of Tempranillo with Cab Sauvignon and Merlot. Aromas of black cherry, spice, aged cheese and earth are solid, while the palate features good fruit but some weakness in structure. Flavors of black cherry and berry are rich at first but fade fast, while the finish is nice but short on complexity. Drink now through 2012.
Name: Carmelo Rodero 2005 TSM  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Definitely a once-ripe, raisiny wine with hard Toro tannins and molasses aromas and flavors. Borderline syrupy but with enough structure and grip to make the grade. Warming and rich wine, with a fierce strucutre and big tannic framework. Drink now.
Name: Cyan 2003 12 Meses  (Toro)

Description: A heavier style of Rioja, with raisin and prune aromas and a brandied character. The palate is expectedly flush and ripe, with weight and size along with black cherry and herbal tea flavors. Shows good stamina and fullness on the finish. Ready to drink now before it starts to fade.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2004 Barón D'Anglade Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Full, ripe and so tannic in its present form that it's scratchy and hard on the mouth. Aromas of ripe berry and syrup hint at its core power, while flavors of blackberry, fresh raisin and chocolate are true and good. A powerpacked wine with a fierce mouthfeel; only time can bring it around. Hold until 2011.
Name: Bodegas y Viñedos Rauda 2004 Tinto Roa Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Quite rustic smelling, with hickory smoke, barbecue sauce, spice and cola aromas. Like most Cigales wines, it has a firm tannic bite and a grating mouthfeel. But the flavors of roast berry, black plum and savory marinade is good and par for the course. Drink now.
Name: Val de Los Frailes 2003 Pago de las Costanas Tempranillo (Cigales)

Description: Maturing fairly well, with brown edges to the wine's earthy hue. The nose is rooty and deep, but there's a definite cheesy, mildly bretty accent to it. And the mouthfeel is defined by major tannic grip and bite. Warm and mildly raisiny, with caramel on the finish. Drink now.
Name: Cyan 2001 Pago de la Calera  (Toro)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Aromas of rubber, smoked beef, syrupy berry and buttery oak are inviting enough, while the palate has edgy acidity that pushes the wine's black cherry element while cutting an obvious oak dosage. Accents of tea, herbs and spice give it character; finishes with an obvious kick of butter and resin.
Name: Emilio Moro 2006  Ribera del Duero

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Slightly saucy on the nose, with jammy, baked fruit aromas hinting at cherry and raspberry. The palate feel is a little tough but healthy, with red fruit flavors accented by vanilla and coconut. Tight, crisp and showing a final wave of tomato on the finish.
Name: Mesoneros de Castilla 2006 Roble  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A little saucy and leathery on the nose, but there's also licorice, blackberry and woody aromas to ponder. Flush and well composed on the palate, with plum, raspberry and mild salty, savory notes. Finishes with good feel but a slight herbal taste of tomato and/or oregano.
Name: Bodegas Qumrán 2005 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Aromas of Christmas spice, pepper and dried fruit fall more into the traditional category than modern, while the palate is snappy, a little lean and delivers strawberry and raspberry fruit with a light buttery oak note. Tight and dry on the finish, but lean. Ready to drink.
Name: Marqués de Vargas 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Firm, earthy and rubbery aromas lead to a tight, focused palate with robust black cherry in the lead and black tea and coffee notes along the side. Toasty, dark and a touch bitter on the finish, and overall it's a solid crianza with condensed flavors and a basic mouthfeel.
Name: Ramirez de la Piscina 2006 Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Bursts with bright, linear cherry and raspberry aromas and flavors, but it's not caustic, sharp or grating. Acidity at peak power yields a zesty, racy personality while a blanket of vanilla flavor softens the cherry and raspberry fruit. Crisp and a good food wine.
Name: Vallobera 2006 Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Lean, focused cherry and raspberry aromas properly portend a snappy, fresh, edgy palate of semitart red plum and raspberry flavors. Buttery oak brings some softness, while the finish is a bit hot and high in acid. More traditional in style than modern.
Name: Luis Cañas 2006 Crianza  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Opens with tight black cherry and raspberry aromas, but also a whiff of pine and chemical. The palate is round, full and tannic, with snappy berry flavors accented by balasmic notes, oak resin and vanilla. Finishes with traditional vanilla-dill notes and a slight stemminess.
Name: Abadía la Arroyada 2005 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Dark purple in color, with can't-miss aromas of prune and raisin. The palate is predictably soft, with manageable heft but low acidity and thus very soft edges. Flavors of baked black fruits are warm but short, and the oak is plentiful. A little too ripe and raisiny to rate higher.
Name: Benjamin Romeo 2006 Predicador  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: An improvement from recent years, but that may be a reflection of when we're tasting the wine. At this point in time it's showing dusty plum and raspberry aromas and good body weight. The flavors of raspberry and cherry are solid, while the finish is cleansing. Beyond palatable; it's really a nice rosé from Tempranillo.
Name: Viña Vilano 2008 Rosado Tempranillo (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Warm, baked aromas smell of clay and raisin, and later a wave of minty green enters the picture. The palate is sort of lean, with some holes in the fabric, while flavors of wild berry and black fruits fold in a heavier note of molasses. Limited in its virtues; short in complexity.
Name: Conde de San Cristóbal 2006  Ribera del Duero

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rubber and berry aromas are solid if standard, while the palate has freshness and bounce along with cherry, raspberry and rubbery latex. Slight amounts of heat and bitterness show up on the finish, but overall this is an entirely functional young wine.
Name: Torrederos 2008 Tinto  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Dark and powerfully oaked despite its 5-month pedigree. Mint, tar, shoe polish and blackberry work the bouquet, while the palate is structured and tight but also quite dark and woody. Mocha, butter and pepper flavors carry the finish on this healthy and structured wine that may also be too oaky for its own benefit.
Name: Monteabellón 2008 5 Meses en Barrica  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Raspberry and cherry are the fruit components on this wholly basic, grabby and oaky youngster. The palate is creamy and wood-riddled, with milk chocolate and carob flavors running side by side with basic red berry fruit. A typical RDD joven that is decent but won't turn many heads.
Name: Bracamonte 2008 Roble  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Hard aromas of matchstick, bramble and tart fruit don't exactly qualify as friendly, while the palate is grabby and tastes of fruit punch and herbal berry. Short and a touch burnt tasting on the finish. Acceptable, as it leaves you wanting more.
Name: Condado de Oriza 2008  Ribera del Duero

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Smells like a dog badly in need of a bath, and alongside those funky aromas there's berry fruit and bubblegum. The palate is forceful and sort of heavy and tannic, with herbal, semitart plum flavors. Bright and lively, but unsophisticated, with poor aromas.
Name: Pago de los Capellanes 2008 Joven Roble  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A beautiful Ribera-style wine with deep earth, tobacco and black fruit aromas. The palate is super dense and extracted, but balanced. Blackberry, fig and chocolate flavors lead to a finish of fine French butter, herbs, coconut and vanilla. Nothing phony here; a real contender among full-bodied, modern-style reds. Drink now–2015.
Name: Abadia Retuerta 2006 Pago Negralada Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Potent and promising on the nose, with rich, deep black fruit, coffee and deftly applied oak. As it airs out it only gets better, with driving berry fruit flavors, thickness, structure and trimmings like clove, baking spice and exotic spices. Long and pure on the finish, and outstanding as a whole. The best Rodero wine we've rated to date; drink now or hold through 2015.
Name: Carmelo Rodero 2004 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is an amazing first effort for Gordon brothers, from five-year-old vines. Earthy and deep, it's loaded with coffee grounds, funk, meat and super-rich black fruits. The color is almost black, and after you pass a little dip in the midpalate, the wine powers into an exceptionally long, smoky, roasted coffee finish.
Name: Gordon Brothers 2007 Tempranillo (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: Same score and overall quality as the year before, which is something to celebrate. The nose features rosy red fruit aromas and touches of classic dill and vanilla. Clear, pure and driving in the mouth, with fine tannins and acidity. Finishes with mocha and coffee. Covers the angles. Drink now through 2015.
Name: R. de Ayala Lete E Hijos 2005 Deóbriga Selección Familiar  (Rioja)
Winery: R. de Ayala Lete E Hijos

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Robust and rich in style, with big aromas of bacon, violets, wild herb, shoe polish and more. The palate is exuberant and generous, while the flavors of toasty black fruits, earth and mocha are nicely presented. Shows a little heat and roughness, but that will settle with bottle age.
Name: Finca El Quiñón 2006 Chafandin  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Starts with a mocha blast, meaning the vanilla, coffee, chocolate and cream aromas are unavoidable and powerful. The palate, however, is properly balanced and shows good acids and tannins. Flavorwise, it's pushing spiced berry, coffee and chocolate, and the finish keeps the wine's lush, generous profile intact. Drink from 2010 through 2015.
Name: Protos 2006 Seleccion  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Starts with leather, aged cheese and other oaky notes, but it settles and unfolds with airing. Smooth, plump and showing a fine mouthfeel, this is a wine that works even if it doesn't overwhelm. Blackberry, cassis and herbal flavors are nice, and the finish is smooth and tastes of fresh coconut. Drink now thru 2010.
Name: Baigorri 2003 De Garage  (Rioja)

Description: Dark and sweet smelling, with mocha, tobacco, briar and a whiff of dried hard cheese. The palate has a rich feel to it and good framing from healthy acidity and tannins, while the flavors of black fruit and berries are bright and forward. Round, chewy, warm and ready to run. Best if held for another year or so.
Name: Elias Mora 2006 Crianza  (Toro)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A very nice wine from a solid producer. The nose displays blackberry, coffee, earth and vanilla aromas, while the palate is pure, respectably tannic and starts with a short but pointed blast of black fruit followed by mocha and vanilla. Makes it to the upper echelon of Ribera wines; drink now through 2012.
Name: Paramo de Corcos 2004 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Serious in size, power and oak, but it doesn't take long to determine that Rodero's '04 reserva is a more complete and pleasing wine. That said, this Ribera with 15% Cabernet and 10% Merlot is still a success; it is mostly coffee and chocolate on the nose, and then saturated berry, savory flavors and lemony oak on the palate. Big and bawdy red wine; needs another few years to settle.
Name: Carmelo Rodero 2004 Viñas de Valtarreña  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Approachable right away, with jammy dark berry fruit aromas followed by a thick, stout palate of black plum and creamy blackberry flavors. Like any good Toro wine, this is broad, tannic and powerful, with black licorice and bitter chocolate on the finish. Good now through 2011.
Name: Muruve 2005 Reserva  (Toro)

Description: A complete wine with a bold bouquet strengthened by ample oak. Ripe, portly and smooth in the mouth, with dark fruit flavors touched up by herbal tea and tobacco accents. Long and chocolaty on the finish. Chewy and a bit tannic; drink now through 2011.
Name: Baigorri 2003 Reserve  (Rioja)

Description: Deep and dark, with attractive berry aromas. No mulchy, overoaked interference at all; it's a clean wine with a medium-to-full body and lightly buttered berry, cherry and raspberry flavors. A mouthfilling, honest Rioja reserva with texture and a bit of vanilla on the finish.
Name: Marqués de Cáceres 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: A big wine with a big price, F de Fuentespina is toasty and dark like blacktop. The nose features scents of savory sauce and marinade, while the feel is thick, rich and creamy. Dark fruit is front and center, but it's undeniably saucy and roasted, which may be due to partial aging in Eastern European oak. It also weighs in at a hefty 15% alcohol.
Name: Bodegas Fuentespina 2004 F  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Earthy and round, with deep fruit aromas accented by coconut, resin and aged cheese. Smooth and comfortable on the palate, with blueberry and black cherry flavors along with an herbal hint. Well cushioned on the finish and nicely done overall. Drink now through 2011.
Name: Bodegas Ribón 2006 Tinto Ribón Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Very dark and loaded with warm blackberry aromas. The palate is bright and shows verve, while the flavors of berry pie are about as dark and ripe as they come. Toasty and chocolaty on the finish, with tight, grabby tannins and classic Toro meatiness.
Name: Finca Anzil 2006  Toro

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Licorice candy and sweet black-fruit aromas control the nose along with a whiff of maple, while the palate is flush, baked and rich, with blackberry and chocolate. The focus isn't 100% exact, so things turn a touch wayward on the back palate and finish. Very good but a touch scattered and generic.
Name: Matarromera 2004 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: This is the wine for those who want Tempranillo to show some sweet ripeness and don't mind the high (15.5%) alcohol that comes with it. It's delicious, forward, intense; the fruit is punchy and sweet, showing wild berry and cherry. The acids are a little chalky, but supportive, and the fruit is highlighted with cola and herb accents.
Name: Abacela 2007 Delfino Vineyard Tempranillo (Umpqua Valley)

Description: Rubbery and dark smelling, with a floral/blueberry element. The palate is thick and wall-to-wall, with sweet blackberry and cherry flavors. Mild but fruity on the finish, with some heat and chocolate. Also a little bit grabby in terms of tannic grip.
Name: Puertas Novas 2006 Vendimia Seleccionada  (Toro)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Ripe fruit on the nose is accented by graham cracker sweetness and wild herbs. The palate is a little aggressive, but nice. And the flavors of plum, berry and cassis are solid and touched up by an herbal brushing. Composed but a touch acidic and edgy.
Name: Pago de los Capellanes 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Dark in color, this Alentejo version of Tempranillo is a wine packed with spice, dark herbs, rich plums and layers of new wood. It is dense, concentrated, the tannins layering acidity with dryness. Still young, it needs another year's aging.
Name: Herdade do Esporão 2007 Aragonês (Alentejano)

Description: Potent and deep on the nose, with smoky oak, barnyard, vanilla and herbal notes. The palate is drying and tannic, meaning it has grip but not as much balance and structure as would be ideal. Finishes with tea and leafy flavors. Serious wine but lacking a few finishing touches. Drink now.
Name: Luis Cañas 2003 Reserva Selección de la Familia  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Dark, rubbery and slightly herbal, with animal hide aromas yielding to cleaner, darker fruit scents as it opens. Clean feeling on the palate, with cassis, raspberry and cherry flavors. On the finish, it darkens up with toasted oak, chocolate and coffee. Solid Ribera del Duero; drink over the next 12 months.
Name: Paramo de Corcos 2004 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Somewhat reduced and granular on the bouquet, where raisin enters the picture along with coffee and chocolate aromas. A big wine with muscular tannins and a vise grip. Black olive, black cherry and plum flavors set up a tannic, tight finish. Should improve with another year or so of aging.
Name: Martín Berdugo 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Black fruit, licorice nibs, fine-grained oak, leather and aged cheese define the bouquet on this juicy, nicely balanced Ribera wine. Comfortable on the palate, with cherry, berry and cassis flavors, and then long on the finish, with herbs, leather and mild oak spice. Drink now through 2011.
Name: Bodegas Fuentespina 2004 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rich and a little baked, with mildly raisiny aromas that turn granular and sweet with air. The palate is layered and shows good structure, while the flavors of dark fruit are muted but nice. Toast, licorice and bacon flavors carry the finish to a roasty conclusion. Best to drink over the next year or so.
Name: Nuestras Cepas 2004 Raiz de Guzmán  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Earthy and fairly ripe, with black fruit and rubbery aromas. The palate is plenty fresh and juicy, with fine acidity propelling black cherry, blackberry, tobacco and smoked meat flavors. Dry, spicy and a touch leathery on the finish. Good now through 2010.
Name: Luis Cañas 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Sweet but unusual aromas: air freshener, floral hints, wet cement and violet. The palate is heavy and buttery, with dark fruit flavors that pass quickly and are replaced by fatter, more oak-driven tastes. Doubtless the barrel is well drilled into this single-vineyard wine.
Name: Contino 2005 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Sweet aromas of raisin, cola, root beer and tobacco suggest ripeness, yet the palate keeps a firm, gritty feel as it pumps out berry, plum and cola flavors. Arguably a little brandied and warm, but if you drink it soon it will deliver adequate freshness and lots of berry fruit and mocha.
Name: Altanza 2004 Lealtanza Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Smooth and comfortable bouquet, with aromas of raisin, blackberry and marzipan. Falls into the lush, ripe category, with blackberry, plum and mild herbal flavors. Finishes easy, deep and chewy, with chocolate and smoked meat accents. Honest and ready to drink now.
Name: R. de Ayala Lete E Hijos 2004 Viña Santurnia Reserva  (Rioja)
Winery: R. de Ayala Lete E Hijos

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Toasty on the nose, with balsamic notes, mint, wood and a little less fruit than ideal. Solid and good across the palate, with firm black cherry, blackberry, herb and cola flavors. Fairly tannic but not fierce, with a spicy, mildly herbal finish. Drink now.
Name: Viña Arnáiz 2004 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Fairly heavily roasted on the nose, with a ton of toasted oak and rubber. Fortunately the palate is less roasty-toasty, and thus you get full black cherry flavors along with an herbal, leafy hint. Mellow and fairly pure on the finish, with a dash of tobacco.
Name: Carmelo Rodero 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Plenty of dill, vanilla and butter aromas, but it avoids outright woodiness. The palate is dark and the feel is cheek-smacking, with lots of extract and acidity. Fruity, dark and spicy tasting, with licorice and black pepper on the finish. A forward, aggressive style.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2005 Bárbaro Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: Vineyard designated Tempranillo is a new venture for Oregon, but suggests that the vines are of sufficient age to express themselves individually. This has a compact profile, with moderately ripe red fruits, a layer of chalk and earth, a hint of cedar and plenty of acidity.
Name: Abacela 2007 McCorquodale Vineyard Tempranillo (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Very ripe, with berry pie aromas that are soft as a pillow. Pastry and cookie flavors mix with raisin, prune and blackberry on the soft, saturated palate, while the finish is heady, warm and chocolaty. Not a lot of vitality here; richness is its calling card. Drink immediately.
Name: Protos 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: A touch earthy and mulchy, but airing reveals true Rioja aromas of dried berry fruits, vanilla and dill weed. The palate runs fast and true, with piercing acidity pushing red fruit flavors of strawberry and raspberry. Spicy and a little woody on the finish, with herbs and a final dash of dill.
Name: Beronia 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: The lightest of Abacela's Tempranillos, this Cuvée is composed of fruit from the estate and three other sites, coppered in mostly neutral oak. Pleasant and tangy, it has light, young vine fruit flavors and astringent, pushy tannins.
Name: Abacela 2007 Cuvée Tempranillo (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Chunky and fruity on the nose, with a blast of red berry and especially burnt coffee. The palate comes on as fresh and lively, but sort of bland at its center. Flavors of red fruit lean toward medicinal and pickled, while the finish is driving and zesty. Drink now.
Name: Bodegas Epifanio Rivera 2006 Erial  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Cherry, red plum, coffee and mocha aromas are encouraging, yet the palate is a bit more citric and grating than you'd expect. Short on flesh and body but long on juiciness and lively berry and cherry components. Finishes jumpy, with a lemony aftertaste.
Name: Monte Alina 2005 12 Meses en Barrica  (Toro)

Description: Odd to see a 2002 reserva still floating around as a current release, but this is the first we've seen of this leaner-bodied, somewhat strained wine. The nose has burnt leaves and struggles to find a center point, while the palate is coconutty and creamy in flavor but tough in terms of feel. Reflects the tough conditions of '02.
Name: Marqués de Cáceres 2002 Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Lake Chelan, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This tart, acidic, estate-grown wine spent 17 months in half new French and American oak, then another 16 months in bottle prior to release. Wild berry fruit flavors remain fresh and prominent.
Name: Tildio 2006 Tempranillo (Lake Chelan)

Description: A little minty up front, but with solid depth and adequate aromatic complexity. Sharp but vital on the palate, with bursting cherry flavors and a dark element. Piercing acidity is a downfall, as it causes a prickly snap throughout. Begs for food.
Name: Castillo Labastida 2005 Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Faustino VII is a consistent, no-brainer type of Rioja. The fruit is soft and earthy, with backdrop aromas of marzipan and flowers. Flavors of red apple skins and strawberry are fleshy, while the finish is simple but pleasant.
Name: Bodegas Faustino 2007 Faustino VII  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: The E-400 refers to the barrel size (400L), and the wine has a dark, slightly medicinal nose that brings cheese and leather into play. The palate is hard and snappy, with acid-based cherry and plum flavors. Dark on the finish, with bitter chocolate and coffee notes. Tough stuff but solid at its core.
Name: Emina 2005 E-400  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Aromas of dried cheese, leather, dust and creamy oak are not as clean as in previous years, and the palate is brillo-pad scratchy with driving cherry and berry flavors. More tart and sharp than ideal, with mild heat and bitterness. May round into better form with time, but as of now it isn't up to the price.
Name: Pago de los Capellanes 2005 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Dark in color and pretty good in terms of early cherry and cassis aromas. Also fairly oaky for an inexpensive wine, with vanilla and resin notes. The palate is racy courtesy of sharp acidity, while the palate features more vanilla than fruit. Pepper and spice notes help out the mostly fruitless finish.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2008 Bárbaro  (Rioja)

Description: Down the middle and safe, with basic red-fruit aromas accented by leather and earth notes. A little rubbery in the mouth, with average raspberry and red plum flavors. Similar on the finish. Generic but good.
Name: Cueto 2007 Tendencia  (Rioja)

Description: Slightly candied red fruit aromas bring a touch of herbal to the show, and the feel and flavor profile are equally tangy, zesty, lean and edgy. Red fruits are what it's about, and palate cleansing potential is its best attribute.
Name: J. Garcia Carrion 2008 Antaño  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Fairly attractive floral aromas are accented by ripe tomato, blueberry and tarry smoke notes. The palate has size and stickiness, while the flavors of berry, plum and graham cracker feature a sweet, pasty finish. Basic wine with 7% Merlot in the blend.
Name: Sembro 2007  Ribera del Duero

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rubbery, roasted aromas are rustic but solid. Superficial boysenberry, blueberry and herbal flavors control the palate, while the finish and feel are juicy but standard. Seems like an everyday Beaujolais or Dolcetto more than anything else.
Name: Finca Torremilanos 2007 Monte Castrillo  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Inky aromas turn warm and charred, while the sizable palate shows blue fruit flavors and some burn. A little grating and hollow as it unfolds, with a warm, simple finish. Tasty but with some holes in the fabric.
Name: Viña Arnáiz 2007 Roble  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Young and vibrant, but also medicinal and gangly. Dark as night and all black fruit on the palate, but also tannic, grabby and rubbery. Toasted on the finish, which simmers just short of being fiery.
Name: Vallobera 2007 Pago Malarina  (Rioja)

Description: Solid and a touch earthy, with rubbery berry fruit and a bit of herbal essence. Crisp, firm and snappy in the mouth, with berry, cherry and peppery herbal flavors and finish. Nothing but regular; decent for the price.
Name: Vaza 2008  Rioja

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Tight, compact and rubbery on the nose, with a mineral, medicinal edge to the black-fruit aromas. Snappy and hard on the cheeks, with midland berry fruit and a scouring, juicy, woody finish. Lots of red fruit but scratchy and a little medicinal.
Name: Bodegas Imperiales 2005 Finca Helena  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Chunky, earthy lead aromas have a hint of floral raspberry, but the palate is creamy and lactic, with milky cherry and plum flavors followed by a mildly bitter, peppery finish. Fairly solid for the most part, but its burnt and lactic notes don't elevate it.
Name: Bodegas y Viñedos Rauda 2005 Tinto Roa Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Leathery and rubbery at first, with aromatic accents of celery seed, barnyard and melted tar. The palate is lighter than the nose, with herbal plum flavors and a lean, strained body. Thin and fresh, but nothing special.
Name: De Lozar 2007  Ribera del Duero

Description: Leans toward burnt and acrid on the nose, yet the palate is fresh but tight and scouring. Raspberry and red plum account for the flavors, while the finish is quick and fades off quietly. Tart and innocuous, but not problematic.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2007 Royal  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Sort of hard and bitter on the nose, and then distinctly herbal and almost foxy as it opens up. Tough and choppy for RDD, with an angular palate full of buttery red fruit flavors. Tough and rough on the finish as well.
Name: Zumaya 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Tomato, bramble and a mild burnt stemminess don't do much for the bouquet, while the plate is rubbery and young, with plum and basic berry flavors. Standard at best, with scratchy tannins and a dry, bitter finish of mocha and wood.
Name: Torrederos 2005 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Standard red fruit aromas turn less clean and more earthy with air. A wet, acidic style of Rioja with lean, hot red fruit and a peppery, dry finish. Basic and a little bitter; needs food like salty tapas to have a chance.
Name: Rioja Vega 2005 Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Transparent red in color, with dilute light berry aromas. Basic but angular pie cherry flavors are tart even if they're accented by buttery light oak, and the finish is dry but fresh. Simple, tangy and thin.
Name: Bodegas Olarra 2008 Otoñal  (Rioja)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is the third vintage for this rare Washington Tempranillo from Alexandria Nicole. It's a crowd-pleaser, with deep fruit flavors of black cherry candy, wrapped in earthy, dusty tannins. As it breathes the aromas show vanilla, lanolin and spice, and the wine has excellent weight and concentration for such young vines.
Name: Alexandria Nicole 2007 Tempranillo (Horse Heaven Hills)

Description: A stylish wine that's on the spot. The nose deals berry, earth, rubber, toast and vanilla all in integrated fashion, while the palate is full, fleshy, fresh and pure. Flavors of juicy raspberry and plum are developed, while the acidity is pulsing. Shows good winemaking as well as positive raw materials.
Name: Bodegas Roda 2004 Roda I Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Wild flowers, fresh herbs and tobacco aromas add a classic touch to the bouquet, and in the mouth it's alert, with juicy acidity propping up raspberry fruit and oak-based vanilla. Some might call it tangy but there's body and depth to this unfiltered, natural-yeast wine, which can be drunk now but should probably be held for another decade or so. Best from 2014–2019.
Name: R. Lopez de Heredia 2001 Viña Bosconia Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Floral at first, with dark fruit, leather, earth and roasted meat aromas. The mouthfeel is rich and the balance right, while the flavors of black cherry and blackberry are deep, ripe and defined. Chocolaty and thick on the finish; this wine is offering a lot for the price. Drink now through 2011.
Name: Condado de Oriza 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Tobacco, licorice, raisin, dried cherry and a puff of smoke give this healthy gran reserva an inviting, traditional bouquet. The palate is lively yet smooth, with integrated acidity pushing mature flavors of berry, plum, caramel and chocolate. A classic Rioja that is ready to drink.
Name: Beronia 2001 Gran Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Bold, fruity and slightly earthy on the nose, with linear, fresh flavors of cherry, raspberry and plum. There's no shortage of acidity here, so the wine has a zesty, forward character and a snappy finish. Drink now through 2013.
Name: CVNE 2004 Imperial Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Starts out hard and crusty, but finds its place with time. The palate is bright with plum, berry and vanilla shadings, while the finish is dry, toasty and offers up vanilla and coffee accents. Has proper finesse, balance and style, but also a bit of tang and scour.
Name: Bodegas Roda 2004 Roda Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Dark, heavily oaked and smelling of asphalt, shoe polish and chocolate. The palate is rich and saturated, with a muscular mouthfeel and large, integrated flavors of charred blackberry, cola and chocolate. Finishes creamy and a little syrupy, with a touch of mocha.
Name: Monteabellón 2006 14 Meses en Barrica  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Composed and broad, with smoked meat and wild berry aromas. The plum and raspberry palate is snappy but not out of balance, and while the finish is a bit starching, it should go very well with hearty foods like steaks and roasts.
Name: Nuestras Cepas 2006 Páramo de Guzmán Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A bit of leather and rubber give the wine's red-fruit aromas a touch of rusticity, while the palate is thick and rich, with mildly baked flavors of plum and blackberry. Overall it's solid and healthy, with a finish of mocha, coffee and pastry. Good wine for not a ton of cash.
Name: Viña Mayor 2006 Secreto  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Rusty colored, with mature aromas of earth, tobacco, vanilla and dill. It's crisp and lean on the tongue, with tangy, alert flavors of tomato, pie cherry, dill weed and vanilla. Composed but lightweight, and seemingly at its peak as far as drinkability.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 1999 Rioja Bordón Gran Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Dark, stocky and full of smoke, cassis and blackberry aromas. The palate is young and tannic, with jammy, meaty black-fruit flavors and some earth. It may be a touch thin in the middle, but with olive, dry plum and texture to the finish, it gets things right.
Name: Bodegas Imperiales 2006 Abadía de San Quirce Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: A little richer and slightly more oaked than Beronia's basic '06 Rioja, this crianza has a nice red-fruit character, body weight and plump, friendly flavors of raspberry and red plum. With smooth tannins and vanilla on the finish, it comes across as a classic-style everyday Rioja. Drink now through 2010.
Name: Beronia 2006 Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Rich, saturated and dark, with initial aromas of game and salsa and then more typical raspberry and plum. This is a big, ripe-style wine with strong tannic grip, ample oak and jammy berry fruit flavors. It isn't overly complex or elevated in character, but it's rock solid and immensely ripe.
Name: Marqués de Cáceres 2006 MC  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A ripe and rich style, with black cherry, raisin and a hint of candy on the nose. The palate shows some bulk and a bit of raisin, but also bold raspberry and plum. Solid on the finish, where you get a true reflection of the palate and its core fruit flavors. Tannic; drink now and throughout 2010–11.
Name: Cruz de Alba 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: With clean, breezy cherry and plum aromas, this one covers the aromatic basics with aplomb. The palate is balanced, with roundness, width and creamy plum and berry flavors. It finishes pure with a touch of milk chocolate, and overall it's what you want from an under-$20 Rioja.
Name: Altanza 2006 Capitoso  (Rioja)

Description: Stolid and compact on the nose, with generic berry aromas. The plate has a tannic stickiness to it, while the flavors veer toward jammy blackberry. More ripe and young in style as opposed to lean and aged. Molasses on the finish yields a sweet ending.
Name: Ramón Bilbao 2001 Gran Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Good overall, but with a few holes. The nose features dried red fruits, mint, dillweed and spice, while the medium-bodied palate has a slight green underbelly along with plum and raspberry on the edges. Smacks the cheeks on the finish, and then coasts away with a dry, herbal essence.
Name: Rioja Vega 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Plum and blackberry aromas seem a little oily and undefined, while the palate is full, black, tannic, jammy and tastes of black cherry and/or plum syrup. This is a good wine but not a great one, and at the price you might expect more depth, definition and character than what it gives.
Name: Viña Ijalba 2001 Reserva Selección Especial  (Rioja)

Description: Thick and chocolaty, with prune and black cherry aromas giving it a bon-bon bouquet. The palate is creamy in feel but modest in structure. Blueberry flavors are sweet and syrupy, but the layering and complexity could use some work. Good Rioja but not for $75.
Name: Beronia 2004 III a.C.  (Rioja)

Description: This is your classic light-bodied, easy drinking, food-friendly Rioja. It opens with simple berry aromas along with worn leather, while the crisp palate shows citrus, raspberry and a touch of vanilla. Zesty on the finish, too.
Name: Beronia 2006  Rioja

Description: Dusty and earthy, with a dry, low-fruit bouquet that's stalky. The palate has a nice feel to it and good textural balance, but the flavors are dilute and brambly, with a distinct reediness. In summary: good mouthfeel but underwhelming aromas and flavors.
Name: Castillo Labastida 2001 Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A bit sweet and warm on the nose, with a cheesy accent. The palate is snappy and tannic, with plum, berry and a mild lactic edge. With a raisiny finish, this wine pours on the power. Solid for the price.
Name: Finca El Encinal 2007 Roble  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: A bit brown/brickish in color, with an earthy nose of spice, cinnamon, tobacco and baked fruit. It's a traditional-style Tempranillo with some Rioja-like character; it shows dried fruit, citrus peel and tobacco flavors, and then a light leafy finish. Drink now.
Name: Pinord 2005 Clos de Torribas Crianza Tempranillo (Penedès)

Description: On the peppery side, with a peanutty aromatic character, yet when it all airs out it finds a pretty good resting place. The palate is slick feeling, if a touch closed, while the flavor profile consists of roasted red fruit and peanuts. Baked on the finish, with pepper and vanilla.
Name: R. de Ayala Lete E Hijos 2006 Viña Santurnia Crianza  (Rioja)
Winery: R. de Ayala Lete E Hijos

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rubbery and extremely leathery and rustic, with a strong, stretched nose that isn't very inviting. The palate is weighty and sticky, with sweet, clumsy, sauvage flavors followed by a roasted, herbal finish.
Name: Nuestras Cepas 2007 Páramo de Guzmán Barrica  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Dark and forceful, with an earthy nose of tar, leather and baked fruit. The palate has life and size, but also quasi-sharp acidity, while flavors of blackberry carry a lactic, vanilla undertone. Finishes sweet but a little burnt.
Name: Volteo 2007 Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Description: Fresh but very light and dilute, with a dash of cinnamon and dust on the nose. The palate is nothing more than candied watermelon, while the soft body and finish offer almost no acidic kick. Tastes good but feels flat.
Name: Conde de Subirats NV Rosé Tempranillo (Cava)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Warm out of the chute, with raisin and herb aromas. The palate is soft and wide, with chewy berry flavors and a spice-herb accent to the flavor profile. A little baked on the finish; jammy overall.
Name: Altozano 2006 Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Sweet, candied aromas run toward raisin, while the acidic, choppy palate deals both red currant sourness and raisiny sweetness. Finishes short but chunky, with biting acidity. Below-average stuff.
Name: Bodegas Fariña 2007 Spanish Sons Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Burnt and cheesy smelling, with undefined, leafy red-fruit flavors. Hard and tannic in the mouth, with herbal flavors and a hint of green on the finish. Seems less than clean.
Name: Annosus 2006 Nobile  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: A jumbled wine with strange aromas of bacon and wild herbs that are followed by a clipped, scouring palate that's driven by ultrasharp acidity. Too little ripeness and way too much tartness equals a sketchy, unrecommended wine.
Name: Bodegas y Viñedos Castiblanque 2006 Baldor Tradición Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Opens with touches of coconut, mineral, violet petals and sweet black fruits. The mouthfeel is textured and smooth, while the flavors of raspberry, blackberry and plum are deep, delectable and of very high quality. This is Ribera del Duero wine at the optimal intersection of power, flavor and human care and concern. Drink now and over the next four years. Imported by Fine Estates From Spain. Editors' Choice.
Name: Emilio Moro 2005 Malleolus  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A big set of roasted aromas includes hints of smoke, mineral, bacon and black fruit. The palate is balanced and lifted by proper acidity, so the black-fruit flavors do not come across as heavy or cooked. Savory stuff, with vanilla and herb accents on a firm, long finish. Good structure; well-made wine.
Name: Legaris 2004 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Even in a marginal vintage, you should expect a true and polished taste of Toro from Maurodos's Prima label. Blackberry, cherry and plum aromas are bonded by light balsam-like oak, while the palate is structured and delivers plenty of ripe black fruit. Chocolate and pepper on the finish seem right for the wine, which nails the Toro style even if it isn't a blockbuster. Imported by Grapes of Spain.
Name: Maurodos 2007 Prima  (Toro)

Description: Good value for a bear of a wine. It's 80% Tempranillo and 20% Cabernet, and it certainly has teeth. Stocky aromas of blackberry, bacon and tobacco are inviting, while the palate is saturated, tannic and full of black fruit, bacon and brown sugar. Finishes with weight and coffee/chocolate flavors. Not a shy wine.
Name: El Molinet 2007 Red (Valencia)

Description: Covers all the principle bases via aromas of ripe dark fruit, bacon, spice and herbs. The palate is a bit soft but it's serious, with raspberry, cherry and plum flavors. Tastes slightly roasted on the finish, with spice and solid tannins. Ranks as a very good all-occasion red. Imported by Pasternak Wine Imports.
Name: CVNE 2006 Viña Real Plata Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Good and lusty, with dark aromas of kirsch, chocolate, shoe polish, burnt oak and perfume. And while it may lack some focus, the palate is flush with ripe black fruit touched up by wood spice, pepper and herbs. Finishes generous and solid, with olive and savory herb notes. Drink now; 16,800 cases made. Imported by W.J. Deutsch & Sons.
Name: Ramón Bilbao 2006 Limited Edition  (Rioja)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: This Tempranillo is amazingly like a Pinot Noir, with a similar mix of cola, dusty cocoa and sour cherry fruit. Perhaps a bit softer than most Pinots, and absent the vegetal and tomato leaf character that often strikes Oregon wines at this price point; this is a very tasty bottle with a lovely, ripe, round and lightly smoky finish.
Name: David Hill 2006 Tempranillo (Rogue Valley)

Description: With its light leafy aromas and spice notes, this wine takes you back to another era in Rioja. It offers traditional flavors of tomato, nectarine peel and raspberry on a dry, juicy palate. Nothing special but perfectly good for fans of classic everyday Rioja wines. Imported by Admiral Imports. Best Buy.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2005 Rioja Bordón Crianza  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: This warm-vintage crianza has earthy black-cherry aromas along with leather, mineral and bacon. The palate is tight, with tanninc grip and narrow but tasty cherry, plum and dry herbal flavors. A savory wine with attributes and good charisma. Drink now. Imported by Classic Wines, Inc.
Name: Paramo de Corcos 2003 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A little old school with its dill and vanilla aromas and flavors, but with leather, raisin and berry accents and a nice medium-deep body, it more than gets the job done. The palate features herbal plum and berry flavors, while the finish is a bit short on fruit and long on dill. Improves with airing; drink now. Imported by Freixenet USA.
Name: Valdubón 2003 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra Contraviesa Alpujarra, Andalucia, Spain
Description: There's no shortage of power here. Forward berry aromas mixed with earth and leather ring true, while the palate is layered, broad, chewy and offers bright cherry and plum flavors. It dries out well on the finish, leaving tasty notes of pepper and herbs. From the Granada area.
Name: Dominio Buenavista 2006 Veleta Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra Contraviesa Alpujarra)
Region: Vino de la Tierra Contraviesa Alpujarra

Description: Apparently the allure of Rioja proved too great for the Torres family, because now they have a wine from Spain's signature region. Ibéricos is dark and fruity, with exotic perfume notes and also some soupy qualities. The flavors of strawberry and raspberry have a thick creamy accent, while vanilla and dill are prominent on the finish. Imported by Dreyfus, Ashby & Co.
Name: Soto de Torres 2006 Ibéricos  (Rioja)

Description: Dark, sweet and arguably a little raisiny on the nose. That sweetness translates into a thick mouthfeel cemented by weight and a tannic grip. The flavor profile is moderately baked, with berry, chocolate and molasses flavors, while the finish is long but tastes a touch cooked. Imported by Grapes of Spain.
Name: Bodegas Abanico 2007 Eternum Viti  (Toro)

Description: Dry and fiery, with leaf and herb aromas going head to head with light raspberry. The palate has some depth and sweetness to it, and at the core it's showing cherry, plum and spice flavors. True to the blueprint of traditional Rioja but not a lot beyond the basics. Imported by Frontier Wine Imports.
Name: Heras Cordon 2005 Vendimia Seleccionada  (Rioja)

Description: Earthy, leafy compost aromas are initially evident on the nose, and while the wine has some feel issue due to an abundance of raw tannins, it eventually rounds out and delivers oily, herbal flavors of blackberry and plum. Dark and muscular, but also aggressive and beefy. Seems a little untamed for a Telmo Rodriguez wine. Imported by Vintus LLC.
Name: Telmo Rodríguez 2007 Dehesa Gago  (Toro)

Description: Lightly fragrant and fruity on the nose, with earth and leather to give it meaning. The palate is medium-weight, with fresh berry and cherry flavors along with finishing notes of pepper and tobacco. Rumbles along like a good, everyday, classic Rioja. A throwback in style. Imported by Palm Bay International.
Name: Bodegas Faustino 2004 Faustino V Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Big and heavy, with forceful aromas of shoe polish, tar and balsam wood. It's saturated and dense in the mouth, but the cherry and blackberry flavors are tart and underdeveloped. And the finish falls off fast. Imported by Baron Francois Ltd.
Name: Viña Ijalba 2005 Dionisio Ruiz Ijalba  (Rioja)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Smells a little fiery, although you do get decent cherry and raspberry from the nose. Solid enough in the mouth, with ripe plum and black cherry flavors in front of a candied, vanilla-ladened finish. Pretty good, with commercially viable sweetness.
Name: Tapeña 2007 Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Rather baked and heavy, with chunky black fruit and chocolate on the nose. First in line on the palate is raisin and prune, while in back of that there's vanilla, dill and brown sugar. With grating tannins and excess weight, this one has balance issues while still offering some good looks at Ribera del Duero. Imported by Admiral Imports.
Name: Finca El Encinal 2002 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Given the price, this wine is more than acceptable and may even be pleasing for those not seeking greatness. It is punchy and grapey, with a bit of dried cheese on the nose along with berry and plum. It's sizable, loud, concentrated and tastes pretty good. Among $7 wines, it's recommended.
Name: Bodegas San Martín 2007 Ilagares Tinto Red (Navarra)

Description: Big and baked, with aromas of cheese and leather offsetting sweet black fruit. Flavors of cola, blackberry and chocolate are as baked and sweet as the nose, and the feel is grabby and leaves a sugary residue on the finish. Wants to be a modern, ripe wine but proves to be simple and overdone. Imported by The Portfolio Group.
Name: Baigorri 2004 Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: A hint of burnt leaves and compost draws down the bouquet, but overall this is a decent $9 wine. It's crisp, acidic and a little stemmy, but amid the leanness it also has an appealing fresh quality that emphasizes red fruit, pepper and snap.
Name: Viña Sardasol 2007 Tempranillo (Navarra)

Description: A decent old-school throwback, with dried spice, pepper and slight red-fruit aromas followed by a light-bodied palate of plum and raspberry. While it's mostly lean, there is the smallest note of caramel and toffee to the finish. Drink now.
Name: Artiga Fustel 2001 Tierra Serena Tempranillo (La Mancha)

Description: Peppery and lightly herbal on the nose, with a whiff of dry red fruits. The palate is pretty snappy and angular, however, the red-fruit flavors mixed with pepper and spice ring true. Finishes dry without a whole lot of carry. Imported by Classic Wines, Inc.
Name: Bodegas Olarra 2004 Cerro Añon Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: A fleshy, simple wine with gumball aromas. The palate is chubby but not all that structured, with plump but basic berry and plum flavors. The finish shows some blackberry but not much else. Good and generally clean, but rudimentary. Imported by Pasternak Wine Imports.
Name: CVNE 2006 Crianza  (Rioja)

Appellation: Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: A tiny bit earthy and peppery, with solid berry fruit aromas. The palate is sappy and medium-weight, with red-fruit flavors dominated by raspberry. Shows a touch of mocha/chocolate on a dry, basic finish. Imported by Bourgeois Family Selections.
Name: Tikalo 2007 Rubens Tempranillo (Tierra de Castilla)

Description: Best early and then it shows its lesser pedigree later on. Early aromas of ripe berry fruit aren't bad before they shift to measurably jumpy and edgy. There's black cherry candy flavors and then snap, crackle and pop on the tongue. Good for the price.
Name: J. Garcia Carrion 2008 Opera Prima Tempranillo (La Mancha)

Description: Modest fruit aromas and a touch earthy and burnt smelling, with lively, somewhat tart raspberry and plum flavors. A bit of vanilla and caramel comes on late, and overall this ranks as a standard, lean-style Rioja. Imported by Admiral Imports.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2004 Rioja Bordón Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: Standard berry along with warm, earthy aromas give it some size, and the palate shows medium-bodied raspberry and strawberry flavors. There's a forward, semiracy feel to it, but in the end there isn't a whole lot of finish, flavor or finesse.
Name: Spanish Vines 2006 Crianza Tempranillo (La Mancha)

Description: Pleasant but very basic, with a nose of dry cherry and a palate that's crisp, lean and features flavors of tart plum and cherry. A decidedly crisp and lean style of Rioja, with no richness to speak of save for a hint of butter on the finish. Imported by Classic Wines, Inc.
Name: Bodegas Olarra 2006 Añares Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Stemmy and rough out of the blocks, with aromas of rubber and strawberry. Seems grabby in the mouth due to rather rough tannins and high acidity, and overall the wine seems forced but lacking in the essentials. Quite expensive given the result. Imported by Frontier Wine Imports.
Name: Heras Cordon 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: A heavy aromatic dose of funk, bramble and rubber is what greets you, and that reduced awkwardness never leaves the wine. Size and in-your-face leather and animal notes are dominant traits, and only below that do you find blackberry, plum and any mellowness. A good mouthfeel is the wine's saving grace. Imported by Frontier Wine Imports.
Name: Estancia Piedra 2007 Azul  (Toro)

Description: Opens with dried red fruit and cinnamon aromas, but after that the mouth is creamy and grabby, with bland fruit and then a wave of vanilla cream and milk chocolate on the finish. A sticky wine that doesn't fully pass the balance test.
Name: Viña Albali 2002 Gran Reserva Red (Valdepeñas)

Description: Dark fruit aromas come with a grainy, almost chemical side, while the palate feels gritty as it pushes licorice and black cherry flavors. Rubbery and without much finish. Imported by American Northwest Distributors Inc.
Name: Tertius 2007  Toro

Description: Immediately this wine plays soft and raisiny. The nose has a stout molasses component, and the palate is sweet and vanilla-infused. A sticky strawberry flavor is sweetened up by coconut and vanilla on the finish. Not well balanced. Imported by Quintessential Wines.
Name: Bodegas Navarro López 2002 Old Vines Gran Reserva Tempranillo (Valdepeñas)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Same score as the prior vintage, and pretty much the same tart wine. It's red in color, sweet and candied on the nose, and awkward in general. And then it's citric and sour in the mouth, with flavors of pink grapefruit. Imported by Grapes of Spain.
Name: Finca Torremilanos 2008 Monte Castrillo Rosado Tempranillo (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Decent aromas but overly acidic and astringent. The cherry flavor is so sour that any vanilla or oak that may come on late can't save the day. Imported by Baron Francois Ltd.
Name: Viña Ijalba 2004 Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla, Central Spain, Spain
Description: Herbal, green and grassy, with less than fresh fruit character. The palate has a weedy taste, while the finish is green and peppery. Edgy mouthfeel; barely acceptable red wine for the second straight vintage.
Name: Cubo 2007 Tempranillo (Vino de la Tierra de Castilla)
Region: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

Description: Red licorice candy on the nose is the only sign of life. Otherwise it's just sour and dried-out, with flavors of citrus and plum skins. Past its prime.
Name: Gran Oristan 1998 Gran Reserva Red (La Mancha)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is light and lightly herbal, an elegant take on the grape, and a good food wine. As with all Seven Hills wines, this is done in a moderate, sippable style; it is balanced and true to the variety but may seem less than perfectly ripe to some palates.
Name: Seven Hills 2006 Tempranillo (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Light chocolate, baking spice, clove—this wine tastes almost exclusively of barrel. There are hints of light strawberry and lunch meat in the aromas. The vines are young and seemingly the fruit has no power or varietal character; the heavy oak and hot finish do not help.
Name: Kennedy Shah 2007 Tempranillo (Rattlesnake Hills)

Description: Termanthia is the pinnacle of Tinta de Toro. Aromas of wild blackberry, crude oil, forest floor and truffles are just now showing themselves, while the tight, tannic palate is full of black plum, blackberry and bitter chocolate flavors. Espresso and roast meat notes grace the dark, jam-packed finish, and as a whole this is one bold, boisterous wine. Best in 2011 thru 2013. Only 531 cases.
Name: Numanthia 2006 Termanthia  (Toro)

Description: Dense and dark, with huge black-fruit aromas, toasty oak, chocolate and balsamic notes. Numanthia is ripe, rugged and intense, with in-your-face black fruit, coffee and burnt-toast accents. The feel and finish are deep as a cool well, and smooth as a whistle. Masculine to the max, and pretty close to being ready to drink. Best to hold until the fall or winter. 12,000 cases made.
Name: Numanthia 2006 Numanthia  (Toro)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Astrales has really nailed it the past couple of years, and while the '06 isn't quite as good as 2005, it's still an excellent wine. Blackberry, tobacco and cocoa aromas lead into a stacked flavor profile of boysenberry and plum. And on the finish it expands and brings vanilla and fudge into play. Drink now and over the next six years.
Name: Astrales 2006  Ribera del Duero

Description: Dark, rubbery and focused on the nose, while the palate is wider, richer and propped up by a band of zesty acidity. The flavors are typical of Toro, meaning dark blackberry and boysenberry. A finish of brandied berries, kirsch and chocolate is almost like dessert.
Name: Numanthia 2006 Termes  (Toro)

Description: A forward wine with earthy aromas, leather and a hint of Navarra's herbal essence. The palate is full-bodied and complete, with balanced weight and tannic structure. Flavors of dark berry and black plum are deep and mildly roasted, while the finish is meaty and chocolaty. Chivite Colección 125 is often Navarra's best red wine, and that appears to be the case in 2004.
Name: Bodegas Julián Chivite 2004 Colección 125 Reserva Red (Navarra)

Description: The nose is all dense blackberries, while the palate is deep, flashy and ripe, with flavors of black cherry and blackberry. If you like big, bold wines, then this one should strike you in a good way; it's saturated and dark, with a touch of vanilla and mocha on the finish. Great balance for such a big wine. Drink now through 2012.
Name: Muruve 2006 Élite  (Toro)

Description: Purple in color and meaty on the nose, with a hint of raisin and reduction but not too much. Due to the heat of 2003, this is a ripe, rich wine with big plum and berry flavors but also good balance and feel. It covers all the bases and finishes in a smooth, solid, stylish way. Just reaches the cut of excellence.
Name: Remírez de Ganuza 2003 Fincas de Ganuza Reserva  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Ripe, dark, a little oily and totally compelling from an aromatic standpoint. The palate is right where it should be, as neither the tannins nor the acidity are out of whack. Boysenberry, blackberry and plum flavors carry an herbal touch, and the finish is layered, with a lasting impression of coffee.
Name: Conde de Siruela 2005 Reserva  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: The aromas are powerful and just the slightest bit brambly. A little hot and rugged on the palate, but loaded with prime black fruit, pepper and mocha notes. It's a potent wine with meaty blackness and plenty of raw power. With 65,000 cases produced, it's not a “boutique” wine, as evidenced by the friendly price tag.
Name: Muruve 2006 Crianza  (Toro)

Description: A mixture of baked fruit, bacon, asphalt and leather aromas is impressive, and so is the bright, composed palate and its flavors of plum, raspberry and tobacco. It's crisp and zesty, which is probably reflective of the cool 2002 vintage, but still it's a very nice wine with depth and dexterity. Drink now.
Name: Luis Alegre 2002 Vendimia Seleccionada  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: A big, ripe and earthy wine, with some baked black fruit and chocolate to the nose. Far more saturated and dense than Siruela's other Ribera wines, but amid the heft there's rich plum and roasted berry flavors and good overall balance. The finish has an herbal tinge.
Name: Conde de Siruela 2006 Élite  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: This is lighter in mouthfeel than the other Tertulia reds, but with tasty toast, vanilla and caramel balancing fresh red fruits. Despite its lightness, it shows a lot of flavor and persistence, and it should benefit from a bit more bottle time.
Name: Tertulia 2007 Les Collines Vineyard Tempranillo (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Violet and blackberry aromas are an inviting first act, while the palate is lush and fairly deep, with thick blackberry and mildly brambly flavors. Maybe it doesn't reach the penthouse, but as Ribera del Duero goes it more than makes the grade. 45,000 cases made.
Name: Conde de Siruela 2006 Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Opens with exotic, earthy aromas and lots of black fruit, but it turns more quiet and timid with airing. The palate shows plenty of bright acidity and some heft and grab, while the flavors of dark berries and plum are accented by light herbal notes and other common Ribera accents like thyme and oregano.
Name: Xavier Flouret 2005 Pavo Real Crianza  (Ribera del Duero)

Description: Dark plum aromas are sweetened and softened by oak-based coconut aromas, while the color and weight are deeper and darker than average. The palate is full, ripe, semicushioned but also acidic and vital, with black fruit, mocha and coffee notes. It finishes chocolaty, with a slight herbal note.
Name: Baron De Ley 2006 Finca Monasterio  (Rioja)

Description: Dried fruit, a touch of compost and then bold coffee and mocha aromas give the wine a decent nose, and the palate, while zesty and snappy, is endowed with pretty good raspberry, cherry and strawberry flavors. Overall it's fruity and ready to drink but fairly ordinary, and while we like the wine we can't say it's a knockout.
Name: Bodegas Franco-Españolas 2001 Barón d'Anglade  (Rioja)

Description: Earthy black cherry aromas give this easygoing Rioja an honest and true nose. The palate is almost what you'd call flush, but on the other hand it's snappy and fresh, with commendable black cherry and plum flavors. With a touch of oak and mocha on the finish, it's a complete wine that should come across familiar.
Name: Bodegas Bilbainas 2006 Viña Zaco  (Rioja)

Description: A solid, earthy style of Navarran red wine, with plum, berry and meaty aromas. The palate is forward, with solid flavors of tobacco, plum, tomato and leather. More fruity than herbal, with heat, thyme, mocha and coffee on the finish. Tastes like something from the Old World. Not currently imported.
Name: Bodega del Romero 2005 Malón de Echaide Crianza Red (Navarra)

Description: Round, mossy and deep smelling, but austere in the mouth. A berry and plum flavor profile is infused with tomato and herbal notes, while the finish is long, healthy and cleansing. Very sturdy and Navarran in every sense because it blends juicy fruit with cool-climate typicity. Good but not for fans of sweet, bulky, superripe reds.
Name: Finca Albret 2004 Crianza Red (Navarra)

Description: Gets going with earthy, lightly leathery aromas of red fruits, and that bouquet is backed by lively raspberry, plum and fresh-tomato flavors. It's not narrow, but it's hardly broad either. Finishes with a lively herbal note.
Name: Ochoa 2005 Crianza Tempranillo (Navarra)

Description: Opens with marshmallow-like sweetness on the nose, but that changes to lean fruit and saline with time. The palate is solid and zesty, with standard Rioja-style plum, berry and dill flavors. It's a fresh but quiet wine, with a tight body, medium tannins and pretty good flavors. Well done but nothing unusual.
Name: Montecillo 2003 Reserva  (Rioja)

Description: TR stands for Tinta Roriz, the dominant grape in this blended wine (with Touriga Nacional). It is smooth, polished, with a spice and mint character, juicy and fruity. The tannins may be dry, but they in no way inhibit the exuberant fruit.
Name: Caves Aliança 2006 Vista TR Tinta Roriz (Beiras)

Description: Initially it smells a bit cheesy and drawn, but with time it evolves to show plum, raspberry and tire rubber aromas. In the mouth, it's tight, fresh and a little gritty, with red-fruit flavors of cherry and raspberry. Not overly generous in terms of mouthfeel, but it does push the fruit until the final bell. More of a food wine than a solo sipper.
Name: Malumbres 2005 Reserva Red (Navarra)

Description: Dark, balsamic aromas blend with hints of wood, bramble and briar to give this wine rusticity, while the palate is slick and medium in weight, with black-fruit and tea-like flavors. It's a little narrow on the finish, but there's also a creamy, oak-driven vanilla flavor that softens things up. A good wine that's 70% Tempranillo and 30% Garnacha.
Name: Bodegas Escudero 2006 Becquer  (Rioja)

Description: Herbal aromas come with bell pepper and berry fruit notes, while the palate is solid in terms of feel but shows classic Navarran flavors of jalapeño and green pepper. Good texture and mouthfeel, but probably too green for a lot of people. Tempranillo with Merlot and Cabernet is the blend.
Name: Otazu 2004 Dimension Crianza Red (Navarra)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Quite dark, smoky and scented with raspberry purée, this unusual wine has interesting components, but does not yet feel complete. Apart from the very ripe and concentrated raspberry fruit, there are chalky acids and a finish that does not offer much depth or pleasure.
Name: Airfield Estates 2007 Tempranillo (Yakima Valley)

Description: The opening of earth, berry and leather aromas is solid enough, yet the palate is quite acidic, yielding semitart but exact flavors of pie cherry and plum. The finish is tight, with light oak touches. But overall it's on the angular side, with a bit of the razor's edge in terms of acidity.
Name: Bodegas Valdemar 2006 Inspiración  (Rioja)

Description: Early tobacco and mint aromas quickly yield to mossy black fruit, and in the mouth it's fresh and zesty, with mild green-pepper infused plum and cassis flavors. Quite crisp and lean, with herbal influences showing up at all points. Classic Navarran red wine.
Name: Señorío de Sarria 2005 Crianza Red (Navarra)

Description: With raisiny, damp aromas and a flat body, we can only label this Marqués de Murrieta high-ender a miss. While not a disaster, you'd expect more from something labeled Gran Reserva Especial, but instead it fails to capture the essence of Rioja and shows heavy cola, blackberry and truffle flavors as well as deep, dull tannins. Overripe to begin with?
Name: Marqués de Murrieta 2001 Castillo Ygay Gran Reserva Especial  (Rioja)

Description: Cherry and dried cranberry aromas along with the magenta color give this wine a “red” personality, which is confirmed by the crisp red-fruit flavor profile. Fairly light in weight, but juicy and fresh, with cleansing acidity and some sharpness.
Name: Bodegas Barriosa 2005 Sombrero Rojo Crianza  (Rioja)

Description: Baked berry and raisin aromas raise questions about the wine's overall balance, while the plate is sharp and acidic yet tastes of raisin, prune and dried apricots. Rather grabby on the finish. Think slam dancing when approaching this Tempranillo-Garnacha blend.
Name: Bodegas San Martín 2004 Señorío de Unx Crianza Red (Navarra)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Description: Aged in neutral oak and blended with 15% Cabernet Franc, this is a high-toned wine with sharp, vinegary acids, but not much character. Tannins are chewy and mask the fruit.
Name: Cave B 2007 Estate Tempranillo (Columbia Valley (WA))

Description: A tough wine to enjoy. The nose has a cheesy top layer, while the base aromas are of bell pepper and lettuce. It's very tangy and juicy in the mouth, with searing red-cherry flavors and green accents. Snappy and whispy to the max.
Name: Príncipe de Viana 2005 Crianza Red (Navarra)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Black cherry and blackberry aromas are accented by bramble and sweat, so the nose is kind of rough and leathery. The palate, however, is fruitier and cleaner, with dark flavors of black plum and berry riding on firm tannins and good depth. The finish is smooth yet a little short on character.
Name: Carravid 2006  Ribera del Duero

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: There's no lack of color – this is almost impenetrably purple/black. Compact and floral, it opens slowly with nicely layered flavors of blue plum, black cherry, cassis and smoky earth. Tannins are polished and lead into a finish that tastes of black tea and clean, wet soil. Tails off rather quickly.
Name: RoxyAnn 2005 Tempranillo (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Description: The Tempranillo—bud wood from Abacela—was grafted onto 30-year-old Cabernet Sauvignon vines. Not sure how many vintages have been made, but it's too soon to rate the experiment. This is a lightly toasty, rather elegant red with little varietal character, but it's nicely built and perfectly fine for a simple supper.
Name: Valley View 2006 Anna Maria Tempranillo (Applegate Valley)

Description: Dalmau strikes again in 2005! This icon wine from Marqués de Murrieta strikes all the right chords. The nose is round, toasty, warm and exotic, with huge berry and plum aromas sexed up by well-applied, fined-grained wood notes. It's lush but balanced, with mineral, violet and bitter chocolate nuances adding complexity. Husky in size, but maintains its form and balance.
Name: Marqués de Murrieta 2005 Dalmau  (Rioja)

Appellation: Ribera del Duero, Northern Spain, Spain
Description: Heavenly blackberry and fudge brownie aromas give this a bouquet that generates a wink and a smile. The mouth is succulent and graced by flavors of black plum, tea, nutmeg and leather.
